title: Woman had to have organs removed after sipping trendy liquid nitrogen drink
text:
Stacey Wagers has filed a lawsuit claiming her internal organs were severely damaged after a waiter poured liquid nitrogen in her glass of water (Picture: Twitter/file photo)

A woman lost her gallbladder and part of her stomach after her organs were badly burned by a smoking drink containing liquid nitrogen.

Stacy Wagers, 45, has since filed a lawsuit claiming a waiter at the Don CeSar Hotel in St Pete Beach, Florida poured the liquid nitrogen into her glass of water to give it a smokey effect in November, 2018.

She said: ‘There was an explosion in my chest’ that occurred ‘within seconds’ of drinking the water.’

‘I couldn’t speak. I felt like I was dying,’ she added.

Wagers had been at a birthday dinner for a friend when one of her pals saw their waiter pour the liquid on a desert that made it ‘smoke.’ Wager’s friend then asked the waiter to pour the liquid nitrogen in their water because they thought it looked cool, according to the lawsuit.

The incident reportedly happened in November at the Don Cesar Hotel (Picture: Google Maps)

Wagers told NBC: ‘Of course I didn’t think it was dangerous at all. He had just poured it on a desert.’

She said she immediately became ill and an ambulance was called to bring a nearby hospital’s Intensive Care Unit – where she was kept for days.

The Chernobyl residents who refused to leave against all government and safety advice

Doctors removed Wagers’ gallbladder and parts of her stomach where tissue had been burned because of the liquid nitrogen’s extremely cold temperature, which can be as cold as -320F.

She said she lost more than 25 pounds after the incident and will have digestion issues for the rest of her life, according to her attorney, Adam Brum.

Brum said: ‘You’re not supposed to just pour it in someone’s drink and allow them to just take a big gulp of this.’

The US Food and Drug Administration warns that liquid nitrogen may be extremely dangerous if consumed.

Woman 'hurled malnourished puppy out of car window'

According to the agency: ‘Both liquid nitrogen and dry ice can cause severe damage to skin and internal organs if mishandled or accidentally ingested due to the extremely low temperatures they can maintain.’

‘As such, liquid nitrogen and dry ice should not be directly consumed or allowed to directly contact exposed skin.’

The Don CeSar hotel has not yet commented on the lawsuit.
description: Stacy Wagers has filed a lawsuit claiming a waiter poured liquid nitrogen in her drink at the Don CeSar hotel in St Pete Beach, Florida
